snippet.title: Canberra Now: ANU college head's apology, and AFP cops avoid jail
snippet.content:
Good morning Canberra! Still a bit damp after yesterday? It should be drier today. But . It's forecast to reach a maximum of 12 degrees and there's only a 5 per cent chance of rain. To find out what's making headlines today, read on and we'll fill you in. College head apologises
John XXIII president Lauran Clifton is speaking out against comments made by college head Geoff Johnston. Photo: Jamila Toderas
Comments about the results of a large-scale university sexual assault survey last week from the head of an Australian National University-affiliated college have been met with backlash. Geoff Johnston on Monday has apologised after John XXIII College students spoke out against what he said. Mr Johnston said to The Canberra Times that the Human Rights Commission's survey captured .
College residents' association president Lauran Clifton said she read his comments with "disappointment and disgust" and approached Mr Johnston about her concerns. Emily Baker Police access database illegally
​Police accessed an AFP database illegally, but were not jailed over the matter.

Two ACT Policing officers illegally accessed the AFP's database for a recording of a confidential CrimeStoppers tipoff, but have avoided jail time. ACT Policing and AFP officers face two years jail for accessing information off the Police Real-Time Management Information System not in line with their official duties. The matter was subject of an internal conduct report, obtained under a freedom of information request but heavily redacted. A criminal investigation was dropped by the internal watchdog after it failed to determine how the officer gained access to the Crimestoppers tipoff. Finbar O'Mallon . Plan protects sun access for Woden
﻿
The Woden Valley, pictured in 2014. Photo: Graham Tidy
The sun will keep shining in more of Woden's town centre, if a revised draft plan is passed. The plan includes a rule for a minimum of three hours of sun a day to be retained to the town square, as well as to adjoining homes. The plan also shows Athllon Drive will be rezoned for higher density housing between Hindmarsh Drive and Callam Street. It reduces the area set aside for a new supermarket east of Callam Street to allow for a small convenience store instead. ​Katie Burgess 'Carer' jailed for sex offences on intellectually disabled woman
A man pleaded guilty to five charges of rape, and eight of an act of indecency. Photo: Louie Douvis
A 74-year-old man who took advantage of a woman with an IQ of 40, and who was 40 years younger than him, has been jailed. He had known the woman since she was 9, and he was fully aware of her intellectual limitations, a court has heard. Her intellectual disability meant she could not consent to sex. "Masquerading as a quasi-carer, the offender took advantage of [the woman] for over three years to satisfy his own sexual appetite," Justice Elkaim said. Alexandra Back Blizzard conditions
Conditions in the Snowy Mountains are set to only get better this week, according to the nearby resorts. Photo: Supplied / Perisher
Thredbo recorded wind gusts up to 133km/h as skiers and snowboarders took to the Snowy Mountains at the weekend. Weatherzone meteorologist Tom Hough said weather at the mountains would ease through the week after being smashed by blizzard conditions. Major resorts have copped more than 70cm of snow since Saturday. Finbar O'Mallon Today's cartoon
